After several years of observing
the present scholastic scheme of the
College of Arts and Sciences, we
arc convinced that our system is
not producing as good results as
some other system might. Reviewing the proposed plan, it appears to
us that the faults we discerne in
the present arrangement are corrected, and that it embodies several excellent new suggestions.
We believe that under the present scheme in the College of Arts
and Sciences, a man 1s ';i:Jlowcdto
spend four valuable, creative years
of his life in too ill-regulated, shortsighted a manner. Withdrawn
from their future world, living in
a scholastic atmosphere, too many
.students have been allowed to
shrink from the vitally important
question of what their future occupation shall be. For too many,
the four years spent in college have
been ones of delay in making this
vital decision and they emerge with
very little preparation for their
life's work. Under the "New
Plan" this condition will, to some
extent at least, be remedied. By
the end of his Sophomore year, a
student must have decided which
of the three groups of study will
best suit him for his post-collegiate
life. The fact that this decision
must be made between three rather
specialized courses of study should
prove a strong stimulus for serious
consideration of the student's qualifications and preferences for his
future occupation.
Another evil of the present system is the taking of courses for
"credits" alone. At this University, many students are -taking
courses which they find neither
valuable nor interesting for the
sole purpose of securing the credits
to be gained by taking them. This,
we have always felt to be a waste
of valuable time. Under the "New
Plan," it seems that this wrong is
to be righted, as the emphasis formerly placed upon credits will be
translated into emphasis gained in
a definite, related field of subjects.
Furthermore, it seems to us that
the importance to be attached to
student research work will prove
valuable in acquainting and impressing the student with his information, while the projected
yearly comprehensive examinations
will make sure that he is retaining
it. For these reasons principally,
we feel that the "New Plan" will
prove itself far superior to the one
it supplants in properly preparing
students of the College of Arts and
Sciences.

extent at least, be remedied. By

student must have decided which
of the three groups of study will
best suit him for his post-collegiate
life. The fact that this decision
must be made between three rather
specialized courses of study should
prove a strong stimulus for serious
consideration of the student's qualifications and preferences for his
future occupation.

courses which they find neither
valuable nor interesting for the

of valuable time. Under the "New
Plan," it seems that this wrong is
to be righted, as the emphasis formerly placed upon credits will be
translated into emphasis gained in
a definite, related field of subjects.

the importance to be attached to
student research work will prove
valuable in acquainting and impressing the student with his information, while the projected
yearly comprehensive examinations
will make sure that he is retaining
it. For these reasons principally,
we feel that the "New Plan" will
